https://prez.dev/description.@value: A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

Boreheole (or well) logging is the practice of making a detailed record (a well log, report or graph) of the geological materials and formations penetrated by a borehole. The log may be based either on visual inspection of samples brought to the surface (geological logs) or on physical measurements made on these samples or by instruments lowered into the hole (geophysical logs). Some types of geophysical well logs can be done during any phase of a well's history: drilling, completing, producing, or abandoning. Logging is performed in boreholes drilled for the oil and gas, groundwater, mineral and geothermal exploration, as well as part of environmental, geotechnical or geological studies.

Core logging is the systematic recording and analysis of drillcores, to provide geological understanding of the materials penetrated by a borehole, and to assist in resource estimation. It employs different methods and techniques to characterize subsurface minerals, rocks and formations, as well as their geometry, structure and relationships relative to depth â€” by observation, measurements and analysis. Although a large proportion of drilling is carried out in the pursuit of mineral and energy resources, core logging is also a critical component of other investigations (e.g. stratigraphic, geotechnical, etc.).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The acquisition of a continuous record as a function of depth, usually graphic and plotted to scale, of observations, analyses or measurements made on the geological materials of the section exposed in a borehole or of the sample (drillcore or cuttings) obtained from it.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).
